Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Experimental Study of an Atomically-Thin, Semiconducting/Metallic Material to Develop Next-Generation Nanotechnology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent explosion in progress towards realizing atomically thin electronics has resulted from the search for newer fabrication methods, materials, and device operation principles that will advance beyond the physical limits of conventional silicon-based semiconductor technology. Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have been shown to undergo a structural transformation to produce a metallic state upon transfer of electrons into the pristine semiconducting material. This gives a route towards atomically sharp metal-semiconductor junctions and could enable a new class of efficient, fully 2D integrated circuit technologies. This project will study the structural change mechanism, and manipulation thereof, in atomically thin TMDs using a scanning tunneling microscope (STM). This instrument features an atomically sharp tip that can directly transfer electrons into the material as well as provide structural and electronic information with atomic-scale precision. Stability as a function of temperature will also be studied in order to inform about suitable operating temperatures for devices. The results of this research will deepen our understanding of control over these materials for nano-device fabrication. This work will be done in collaboration with Professor Michael Fuhrer, a leader in experimental physics research of two-dimensional materials, at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia.

This project aims to correlate atomic structures with local electronic properties at the metallic-semiconducting interface using scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and scanning tunneling spectroscopy (STS). STM and STS will be done at low temperature in the vicinity of a phase boundary to provide topographical characterization of the local electronic density of states. Then, the effect of controllably injecting electrons into the pristine material or into a phase boundary, with attention being paid to phase boundary migration, phase creation, and changes in electronic state can be studied. Phase boundary migration will also be studied as a function of temperature.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Materials that exhibit distinct metallic and semiconducting phases offer a possible route towards realizing unprecedented breakthroughs in integrated circuitry. However, our investigation of the structural phase change in our target phase-change material, tungsten disulfide (WS2), was immediately met with an impassible barrier. While these particular experiments were, unfortunately, fruitless, we were able to study a different material system that generated scientifically impactful results and fostered a larger collaboration than originally anticipated.

Our primary method of investigation was scanning tunneling microscopy  (STM), in which an atomically-sharp, metal tip is brought to within a few tenths of a nanometer near a sample and measures the energy-dependent, quantum mechanical electron hopping between tip and sample to probe the material's electronic structure with atomic-scale spatial resolution. WS2 samples that had been prepared prior to the arrival of the principal investigator suited. However, the nature of their preparation obstructed STM experimentation.

The nature of the problem necessitated preparation of new samples. However, processing new samples was prohibitively time consuming and there was no guarantee they would immediately work for STM. As such, the trajectory of the project changed to a different material system.

An emergent class of materials, topological nodal line Dirac semimetals, offer a robust platform to study unique electron spin states and answer fundamental questions in condensed matter physics due to their unique band structure, and have immediate technological application. Specific materials belonging to this class have been predicted, but many materials best suited for electronics applications have not been experimentally verified to possess such electronic properties due to the inherent difficultly in measuring electronic band structure.

Scanning tunneling microscopy is the perfect tool to map out the momentum-energy relationship of electrons, directly indicative of the material's band structure, in condensed matter. Zirconium silicon sulfide (ZrSiS), which is a predicted Dirac nodal line semimetal, was immediately available to us for study using low temperature STM. Not only is this material is nontoxic, the line-like touching of bands in the energy-momentum space (the phenomenon from which "nodal line" semimetals take their name) has no disruptive neighboring energy bands for electrons to occupy, making it one of the most promising candidate materials for study.

The primary objectives of this study were: (i) Obtain atomic resolution of ZrSiS, (ii) Identify the elemental species at the surface of the material to inform about how to material exfoliates, (iii) Identify the energy-momentum relationship of electrons in both the valence and conduction bands, (iv) Identify energy-momentum locations of the line-like band crossings, (v) Identify theorists and procure their assistance in describing our experimental data. All of these objectives were met, and we observed evidence for novel physics phenomena that were not predicted previously.

Results from this study were presented this year at the American Physical Society's March Meeting, a major physics conference, to scientists hailing from academic institutions around the globe. In addition, our results were recently submitted to a peer-reviewed journal for publication.

In addition to the relationship established between experimentalists at Monash University and the University of Central Florida, new relationships were established via the theoretical support from experts in Singapore and Taiwan. This project also established experimental and analysis techniques in the host laboratory for the first time, which were translated to laboratories in the US and Singapore. The international relationship forged by this project will help keep all partners competitive not only academically, but also in the search for new materials that are of scientific and technological interest. Beyond the scientific impacts of this 8 week program, as an introduction to the culture, infrastructure, flora and fauna (of which there were many wonderful birds and nearly no spiders or snakes), and people of Australia, this experience was phenomenal.
